The ECHAM-HAM global climate aerosol model uses the M7 microphysics model, but its high computational costs make it expensive to run at higher resolutions or for a longer time. We aim to use machine learning to approximate the microphysics model with sufficient accuracy and reduce the computational cost by being fast at inference time. The original M7 model is used to generate data for input-output pairs to train a neural network on it. By applying a special logarithmic transform, we can learn the variables' tendencies, achieving an average R2 score of 89%. On a GPU, we achieve a speed-up of 120 compared to the original model.

Aerosol forcing remains the largest source of uncertainty in the anthropogenic effect on the current climate (Bellouin et al., 2020). The aerosol cooling effect hides some of the positive radiative forcing caused by greenhouse gas emissions, and future restrictions to lower air pollution might result in stronger observed warming. Aerosols impact climate change through aerosol-radiation interactions and aerosol-cloud interactions (IPCC, 2013). They can either scatter or absorb radiation, depending on the particle's composition. For example, black carbon aerosols from fossil fuel burning have a warming effect by absorbing radiation, while sulfate from volcanic eruptions has a cooling effect by scattering radiation. Clouds significantly influence the Earth's radiation budget by reflecting sunlight, and aerosols can change cloud properties by acting as cloud condensation nuclei (CCN). A higher concentration of aerosols leads to more CCN, resulting in more but smaller cloud droplets, which increase the cloud's albedo (Twomey, 1974) and can enhance the cloud's lifetime (Albrecht, 1989).

Many climate models often consider aerosols as external parameters, reading them once and keeping them constant throughout the model run. In some cases, aerosol properties are modeled, but with no distinction between aerosol types, and only an overall mass is considered. To incorporate a more accurate description of aerosols, aerosol-climate modeling systems like ECHAM-HAM (Tegen et al., 2019) have been introduced. It couples the ECHAM General Circulation Model (GCM) with a complex aerosol model called HAM. The microphysical core of HAM is either SALSA (Kokkola et al., 2008) or the M7 model (Vignati et al., 2004), which we consider here. M7 uses seven log-normal modes to describe aerosol properties, with particle sizes represented by four size modes: nucleation, Aitken, accumulation, and coarse. These modes can be either soluble or insoluble. M7 includes processes like nucleation, coagulation, condensation, and water uptake, leading to the redistribution of particle numbers and mass among the different modes. It also considers five different components: sea salt (SS), sulfate (SO4), black carbon (BC), primary organic carbon (OC), and dust (DU). M7 is applied to each grid box independently, without modeling any spatial relations. More detailed models come with increased computational time: ECHAM-HAM can be run at 150km resolution for multiple decades. However, to run storm-resolving models, a 1km horizontal grid resolution is ideal, and the model should still be able to produce forecasts up to a few decades. To achieve this, a massive speedup of the aerosol model is needed.

Emulating Aerosol Microphysics with Machine Learning

Replacing climate model components with machine learning approaches and decreasing a model's computing time has been shown to be successful in the past. There are several works on emulating convection, including random forest approaches (O’Gorman & Dwyer, 2018) and deep learning.
